item.title: TDD with Vibe Coding: Why This Combo Rules the AI Development Era
item.description: The landscape of AI-assisted coding is evolving rapidly, and "vibe coding" has emerged as the dominant trend.
item.dc:creator: Peter
item.content:encoded:
The landscape of AI-assisted coding is evolving rapidly, and "vibe coding" has emerged as the dominant trend. As LLMs become increasingly sophisticated and companies race to improve accuracy and usability, we're witnessing a golden age of AI development tools.

Thanks for reading! Subscribe for free to receive new posts and support my work.

I've extensively tested the major players: Windsurf, Cursor, Claude Code, Lovable, Bolt.new, and Replit. My preferences shift with each new release as different tools leapfrog each other in specific capabilities. Currently, I'm all-in on Claude Code with the Max plan—it's simply the most capable vibe coding agent I've encountered.

The AI Paradox: Power Meets Uncertainty

Despite AI's impressive capabilities, it still makes mistakes. Lots of them. This is precisely where Test-Driven Development (TDD) becomes invaluable. Unlike traditional TDD implementation, which often requires significant setup and planning, AI-powered TDD is refreshingly simple.

With AI, TDD becomes as easy as including a prompt or rule asking the agent to follow TDD principles when writing code or implementing features. This becomes especially critical when dealing with large-scale changes affecting hundreds of lines of code. Having confidence in those changes isn't just helpful—it's essential.

The Unexpected Renaissance of TDD

I've never seen TDD be more accessible or powerful than it is today with AI assistance. It serves as an excellent guide for both AI agents and human developers, significantly improving code quality and developer confidence.

However, this power comes with trade-offs. The token consumption can be substantial, and development speed may initially decrease, particularly on larger projects. The AI might dive deep into your project architecture to understand the codebase and establish comprehensive test cases. Sometimes it fails repeatedly before finding the right approach.

But here's the payoff: once the work is complete, when you see the test coverage and observe how thoroughly your changes are tested, you'll understand the value. The confidence and maintainability you gain far outweigh the initial investment in time and tokens.

The Bottom Line

TDD with vibe coding represents a paradigm shift in how we approach software development. While it requires patience and resources upfront, the long-term benefits in code quality, confidence, and maintainability make it an essential practice for serious AI-assisted development.

The future of coding isn't just about writing faster—it's about writing better, more reliable code with the confidence that comes from comprehensive testing.

item.title: Building in Public Day 27: Why I Made FinOps Recommendations Look Like GitHub Issues
item.description: 27 days into building my FinOps platform in public, and I just had a breakthrough that changed everything about how users interact with cost optimization recommendations.
item.dc:creator: Peter
item.content:encoded:
27 days into building my FinOps platform in public, and I just had a breakthrough that changed everything about how users interact with cost optimization recommendations.

The Problem Every FinOps Tool Faces

Thanks for reading! Subscribe for free to receive new posts and support my work.

Users get overwhelmed with abstract recommendations. "Optimize this instance" or "Right-size that database" sound risky when you can't see exactly what will change. How do you build confidence in cost optimization decisions?

The Solution: Borrow from What Already Works

I redesigned our recommendation system around GitHub's issue and pull request workflow. Here's why this pattern is perfect for FinOps:

  • Familiar Interface: Developers already trust the GitHub review process

  • Visual Diff Views: See exactly what changes before implementing

  • Impact Transparency: Every change shows cost implications upfront

  • Confidence Building: The PR-style review reduces implementation anxiety

The Technical Deep Dive

Beyond the UX breakthrough, I've been building the multi-tenant foundation:

✅ Supabase authentication with JWT security

✅ Proper tenant data isolation

✅ GitHub-style issue cards for recommendations

✅ Enhanced dashboard with search/filtering

🚧 Still working on: Complete diff view integration

Key Lesson: User experience decisions should drive your technical architecture, not the other way around. The GitHub-inspired approach didn't just improve the frontend—it influenced how I structure recommendation data and API endpoints.

What's Next

Day 28 goals:

  • Complete the code editor diff view

  • Add real-time cost impact calculations

  • Get the first user feedback on the new interface

Building in public has been incredible for accountability. Every day I'm forced to articulate what I learned and what's next. It's been the best development process I've ever used.

item.title: Why FinOps Tools Fail (And What I'm Building Instead)
item.dc:creator: Peter
item.content:encoded:
Hey builders,

Day 26 of building in public, and I just had a major realization about the FinOps industry that's completely changed my approach.

Thanks for reading! Subscribe for free to receive new posts and support my work.

Most cost optimization tools are solving the wrong problem.

The Real Problem Isn't What You Think

For weeks, I've been obsessing over making our AI recommendations more accurate. Better algorithms, smarter analysis, prettier dashboards showing exactly where teams are wasting money.

But here's what I discovered: teams already trust the recommendations.

When our AI says "you're wasting $50K annually on oversized EC2 instances," engineering teams don't question the analysis. They believe it.

So why don't they act on it?

The Implementation Gap

The real problem is the terrifying gap between "you should resize this instance" and actually doing it in production.

Every conversation I have with engineering teams comes back to the same fears:

- "What if something breaks?"

- "How do we roll back if this goes wrong?"

- "What if the AI missed something critical?"

Sound familiar?

Most FinOps tools dump recommendations into dashboards and call it done. But that's where the real challenge begins.

What I Built This Week

Instead of building another analysis engine, I focused entirely on implementation confidence:

GitHub-Style Diff View

- Shows exact infrastructure changes with cost annotations

- "$280/month → $140/month savings" displayed line-by-line

- Familiar interface that developers actually trust

Risk Assessment System

- Every recommendation categorized: Low/Medium/High risk

- Clear blast radius analysis for each change

- Confidence scores based on data quality

Implementation Guidance

- Step-by-step rollback procedures for every suggestion

- Integration with Terraform for infrastructure-as-code workflows

- Preview mode showing exact changes before execution

The Core Insight

Teams don't want AI making changes automatically. That's terrifying.

They want AI to make them confident about making changes themselves.

There's a massive difference between:

- ❌ "AI will optimize your infrastructure"

- ✅ "AI will guide you through safe optimization"

The Experience I'm Designing

Instead of the typical FinOps flow:

1. Show recommendations

2. Hope teams implement them

I'm building:

1. Analyze AWS setup with AI

2. Show recommendations with clear risk levels

3. Generate actual infrastructure code for changes

4. Guide through staging deployment and testing

5. Provide production checklist with monitoring

6. Track real savings vs. predictions

Still working on making this seamless, but the early results are promising.

Why This Matters

Perfect recommendations sitting in dashboards = $0 saved.

Implementation confidence > recommendation accuracy.

Every FinOps tool focuses on finding waste (the easy part). Almost none focus on building the confidence to fix it (the hard part).

That's the real opportunity.

What I'm Learning

Building in public has taught me that the most important insights often come from talking to potential users, not from more coding.

The technical challenge isn't generating good recommendations. Our AI already does that with 95% accuracy.

The challenge is UX. Psychology. Trust.

How do you make infrastructure changes feel safe instead of scary?

That's what I'm solving next.

Your Turn

If you've dealt with cloud cost optimization:

What stops your team from implementing recommendations you trust?

Hit reply and let me know. Your insights directly shape what I build next.

Building in public means building with feedback.

---

Peter
